awd_titl_txt: Students, Diversity Events, and a Systems Workshop at the 2022 Summer Biomechanics, Bioengineering, and Biotransport Conference (SB3C); Cambridge, Maryland; 20-23 June 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide support for Students, Diversity Events, and a Systems Workshop at the annual Summer Biomechanics, Bioengineering, and Biotransport Conference (SB3C). The conference will take place in Cambridge, Maryland, June 20-23, 2022. The goal of the conference is to promote research collaboration in bioengineering, specifically the impact of forces and flows on biology and disease. The conference also showcases student research and provides opportunities for students to network with experienced researchers. Funding will be used to offset registration costs for students from groups traditionally underrepresented in biomechanics (including women) to attend the conference. Funding will also be used to pay the full registration cost for students who are selected to participate in a research competition. Finally, funding will be used to support a mentoring event for the aforementioned students, an educational event about African Americans in STEM fields, and a professional writer to disseminate conference outcomes with the larger community. This will be in addition to the publicly-available conference proceedings.

The primary objective of the 2022 SB3C is to promote state-of-the-art research, collaboration, and scientific discourse in bioengineering with a focus on biomechanics, fluid mechanics, biotransport, mechanobiology, tissue engineering, and rehabilitation and design. The second objective of SB3C is to showcase research from students and trainees, as well as provide essential networking and mentoring opportunities. The third objective of SB3C is to broaden participation in biomechanics, bioengineering, and biotransport research. The intellectual merit of the 2022 SB3C lies in advancing knowledge in how to apply concepts from systems biology to biomechanics and mechanobiology. This will be achieved through the plenary talk, research sessions, and workshops. This knowledge will then be disseminated to the larger biomechanics community by publishing a paper in the Journal of Biomechanical Engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the 2022 Summer Biomechanics, Bioengineering, and Biotransport Conference (SB3C2022), which was held in Cambridge, Maryland in June 2022. The conference was attended by 650 students, post-docs, faculty, government employees, and industry engineers. At the conferences, the attendees participated in scientific talks and workshops on topics related to biomedical engineering. The NSF funding specifically supported conference registration and travel for 17 students from 13 universities who had never attended this conference and would not otherwise have been able to attend the conference; a celebration of Juneteenth (309 attendees), which included an educational presentation and a performance by the West African Dance Company KanKouran; a mentoring event, in which 106 trainees were matched with more experienced mentors to discuss careers in biomedical engineering; and the publication of a paper summarizing the scientific outcomes from the conference.

 

Intellectual Merit: SB3C2022 advanced knowledge in how to apply a systems biology approach to biomechanics, bioengineering, and biotransport through the scientific presentations and workshops. The interactions among students, post-docs, faculty, government employees, and industrial engineers generated new research ideas and future research collaborations. SB3C2022 also impacted on engineering disciplines, biology, and medicine since many of attendees have primary or secondary appointments in these departments. The attendees took their new knowledge back to their home institutions and shared it with their colleagues. We also made the scientific topics presented at SB3C2022 available to the broader community through a publication titled, "A systems approach to biomechanics, mechanobiology, and biotransport," which was published in the Journal of Biomechanical Engineering in February 2024. Finally, the Juneteenth program educated bioengineers about Juneteenth and the contributions of African Americans to biomechanics.

 

Broader Impacts: SB3C2022 benefitted society by advancing our understanding of human disease, which contributes to the development of new therapies and devices to improve the quality of human life. SB3C2022 further benefitted society by providing essential mentoring and networking opportunities for young engineers, enabling them to build their careers and encouraging them to stay in engineering. The also conference included a workshop and presentations on biomechanical engineering education, which will further enhance the ability of many universities to educate engineers. Finally, the NSF funding enabled 17 students who did not have the means to attend the conference to attend SB3C2022 and advance their careers by gaining scientific knowledge, receiving career advice from experts in their fields, and networking with colleagues from academia, government, and industry.


Last Modified: 07/23/2024
Modified by: Alisa M Clyne
